Passing a bool as a third argument does not set the variable in the parent scope on xenial/3.5.1. Only the text PARENT_SCOPE does it. How about:

```CMake
if(ign_string_append_PARENT_SCOPE)
  set(${output_var} "${${output_var}}${delim}${val}" PARENT_SCOPE)
else()
  set(${output_var} "${${output_var}}${delim}${val}")
endif()
```

content.raw: Right, if `CXX_STANDARD` is set, then it will piggyback on `PRIVATE_CXX_STANDARD` and `INTERFACE_CXX_STANDARD`, which is why users can only set `CXX_STANDARD` or some combination of the other two.
content.html: Right, if CXX_STANDARD is set, then it will piggyback on PRIVATE_CXX_STANDARD and INTERFACE_CXX_STANDARD, which is why users can only set CXX_STANDARD or some combination of the other two.

content.raw:
First of all, I apologize for not marking this PR as a `[WIP]`, but I have a few significant changes coming down the line soon for this.

It turns out that `find_dependency(~)` doesn't support cmake components until `cmake-3.9`, so we won't be able to use `find_dependency(~)` at all in our `*-config.cmake` files if we want to be able to specify package components to depend on. In some upcoming changes (which are currently testing well on my machine), we'll be replacing all `find_dependency(~)` calls with `find_package(~)` and dealing with the `REQUIRED` and `QUIET` flags in our own way.
content.html:
First of all, I apologize for not marking this PR as a [WIP], but I have a few significant changes coming down the line soon for this.

It turns out that find_dependency(~) doesn't support cmake components until cmake-3.9, so we won't be able to use find_dependency(~) at all in our *-config.cmake files if we want to be able to specify package components to depend on. In some upcoming changes (which are currently testing well on my machine), we'll be replacing all find_dependency(~) calls with find_package(~) and dealing with the REQUIRED and QUIET flags in our own way.

Tragically, it requires a hefty amount of special character escaping, but I don't know what a better solution would be until we migrate to `cmake-3.9`.

content.raw:
This pull request is now ready for review.

I've updated the implementation to make migration much easier for projects that are already using `ign-cmake`. This PR is fully backwards compatible with two caveats:

1. When a project uses the "outdated" macros from `ign-cmake`, an "author warning" will be printed by cmake during configuration. The warning will contain instructions on how to migrate from the old macros to the new macros. The old macros will still continue to work as expected, even as they print these warnings.

2. ~~We should make sure to merge [this ign-msgs PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/49/) before merging this pull request, in order to ensure a smooth transition for our CI.~~

I'll be working on componentizing some of the existing ignition libraries. I've already made a lot of progress on this for `ign-common`, which is definitely the project that most desperately needs components.
content.html:
This pull request is now ready for review.

I've updated the implementation to make migration much easier for projects that are already using ign-cmake. This PR is fully backwards compatible with two caveats:

  1. When a project uses the "outdated" macros from ign-cmake, an "author warning" will be printed by cmake during configuration. The warning will contain instructions on how to migrate from the old macros to the new macros. The old macros will still continue to work as expected, even as they print these warnings.

  2. We should make sure to merge this ign-msgs PR before merging this pull request, in order to ensure a smooth transition for our CI.

I'll be working on componentizing some of the existing ignition libraries. I've already made a lot of progress on this for ign-common, which is definitely the project that most desperately needs components.

content.raw:
I'm thinking the right thing to do here is probably to use `target_include_directories(${target_name} INTERFACE ${${ign_import_target_INCLUDE_VAR}})` and get rid of the loop altogether.

It wound up like this because I tried something like `set_target_properties(${target_name} PROPERTIES INTERFACE_INCLUDE_DIRECTORIES ${${ign_import_target_INCLUDE_VAR}})` and it caused errors during compilation because it tried to treat the entire list as a single directory name. Putting it in a loop appeared to solve the problem, but it probably only removed one problem and introduced another.
content.html:
I'm thinking the right thing to do here is probably to use target_include_directories(${target_name} INTERFACE ${${ign_import_target_INCLUDE_VAR}}) and get rid of the loop altogether.

It wound up like this because I tried something like set_target_properties(${target_name} PROPERTIES INTERFACE_INCLUDE_DIRECTORIES ${${ign_import_target_INCLUDE_VAR}}) and it caused errors during compilation because it tried to treat the entire list as a single directory name. Putting it in a loop appeared to solve the problem, but it probably only removed one problem and introduced another.

content.raw:
Okay, and now I know why I didn't use `target_include_directories(...)`. It gives the following error:

```
CMake Error at /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/cmake/ignition-cmake0/cmake0/IgnImportTarget.cmake:109 (target_include_directories):
  target_include_directories called with non-compilable target type
Call Stack (most recent call first):
  /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/cmake/ignition-cmake0/cmake0/IgnPkgConfig.cmake:108 (ign_import_target)
  /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/cmake/ignition-cmake0/cmake0/IgnPkgConfig.cmake:45 (ign_pkg_check_modules_quiet)
  /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/cmake/ignition-cmake0/cmake0/FindAVUTIL.cmake:19 (ign_pkg_check_modules)
  /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/cmake/ignition-cmake0/cmake0/IgnUtils.cmake:145 (find_package)
  CMakeLists.txt:101 (ign_find_package)
```

There has already been a discussion about this [on kitware](https://gitlab.kitware.com/cmake/cmake/issues/15689), and a solution seems to [have been merged](https://gitlab.kitware.com/cmake/cmake/merge_requests/1264), but I doubt it will be available to us until a much later version of cmake (as of [the 3.10 documentation](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.10/command/target_include_directories.html), you still cannot use `target_include_directories(~)` on an imported target).

I'll see if I can figure out how to set this property for lists in a way that cmake is happy with.

content.raw:
Sort of.

At some point on the `default` branch, the call to `ign_create_docs()` was moved from `ign_create_packages()` to `ign_configure_project()`, and so having this command here was causing cmake errors since `add_subdirectory(src)` was happening twice.

Now it seems that at some point since then on `default`, `ign_create_docs()` was moved back from `ign_configure_project()` to `ign_create_packages()` where it used to be.

Either that, or some very strange wires got crossed during a merge.
content.html:
Sort of.

At some point on the default branch, the call to ign_create_docs() was moved from ign_create_packages() to ign_configure_project(), and so having this command here was causing cmake errors since add_subdirectory(src) was happening twice.

Now it seems that at some point since then on default, ign_create_docs() was moved back from ign_configure_project() to ign_create_packages() where it used to be.

Either that, or some very strange wires got crossed during a merge.

content.raw:
I'm now running into a situation where I have ign-rendering from source and `libignition-common-dev` installed  and the `@PACKAGE_IGN_INCLUDE_INSTALL_DIR_FULL@` variable is generating the wrong path. I looked into this a bit and I **think** this is what's happening:

in ign-rendering this line evaluates to:

~~~
set_and_check(ignition-rendering0_INCLUDE_DIRS "${PACKAGE_PREFIX_DIR}/include/ignition/rendering0")
~~~

The problem is that the variable `PACKAGE_PREFIX_DIR` (created from `@PACKAGE_INIT@` [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/src/4893e6b35e6180c0880ddcfba41fba7c2e4f430c/cmake/ignition-config.cmake.in?fileviewer=file-view-default#ignition-config.cmake.in-49) ) gets overwritten by `find_package(ignition-common1 ${ign_package_quiet} ${ign_package_required})` (created from `@PROJECT_CMAKE_DEPENDENCIES@` [earlier](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/src/4893e6b35e6180c0880ddcfba41fba7c2e4f430c/cmake/ignition-config.cmake.in?fileviewer=file-view-default#ignition-config.cmake.in-84) in this file). 

This is because find ign-common dependency check changes `CMAKE_CURRENT_LIST_DIR` to `/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/cmake/ignition-common1` which then generates `PACKAGE_PREFIX_DIR` with value `/usr`

In the end, it was trying to set `ignition-rendering0_INCLUDE_DIRS` to  `/usr/include/ignition/rendering0` which doesn't exist.
content.html:
I'm now running into a situation where I have ign-rendering from source and libignition-common-dev installed and the @PACKAGE_IGN_INCLUDE_INSTALL_DIR_FULL@ variable is generating the wrong path. I looked into this a bit and I think this is what's happening:

in ign-rendering this line evaluates to:

set_and_check(ignition-rendering0_INCLUDE_DIRS "${PACKAGE_PREFIX_DIR}/include/ignition/rendering0")

The problem is that the variable PACKAGE_PREFIX_DIR (created from @PACKAGE_INIT@ here ) gets overwritten by find_package(ignition-common1 ${ign_package_quiet} ${ign_package_required}) (created from @PROJECT_CMAKE_DEPENDENCIES@ earlier in this file).

This is because find ign-common dependency check changes CMAKE_CURRENT_LIST_DIR to /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/cmake/ignition-common1 which then generates PACKAGE_PREFIX_DIR with value /usr

In the end, it was trying to set ignition-rendering0_INCLUDE_DIRS to /usr/include/ignition/rendering0 which doesn't exist.

content.raw:
Wow, thanks for figuring this out.

As far as I can figure, your fix is as good of a correction as we're likely to find. It's unfortunate that `@PACKAGE_INIT@` uses a generic variable name (instead of a package-specific variable name), but I'm not terribly interested in coming up with a custom replacement for `@PACKAGE_INIT@`.

Interestingly, the current `default` branch already has this swapped. I guess when I moved the location of `@PROJECT_CMAKE_DEPENDENCIES@` in this branch, I just didn't anticipate this issue happening.

Feel free to merge your fix into this branch.

Interestingly, the current default branch already has this swapped. I guess when I moved the location of @PROJECT_CMAKE_DEPENDENCIES@ in this branch, I just didn't anticipate this issue happening.

content.raw: Just out of curiosity: is there any way of creating more than one shared library per project using `ign-cmake` macros? Or should that potential library be a component?
content.html: Just out of curiosity: is there any way of creating more than one shared library per project using ign-cmake macros? Or should that potential library be a component?

content.raw:
I'd say it depends a little bit on the purpose of the library.

If it's an internal library for testing purposes, like gtest, then it should be handled outside the scope of `ign-cmake`, using an ordinary `add_library(~)` command.

If it's a library that we intend to ship and install as part of the project, then it should be added as a component library.

If we have a use case where we want to compile multiple libraries to be part of the "core" of a project but we want to keep them as separate libraries for some reason, we can revisit this macro. I think doing that could create a great deal of confusion, though, if only because it's hard to imagine what kind of naming convention we could even use for those libraries, e.g. `libignition-transport1-core1` and `libignition-transport1-core2`?

So for now, I'd recommend we stick to the design of having one core library and arbitrarily many component libraries. This seems to be a popular pattern among modular library projects.
content.html:
I'd say it depends a little bit on the purpose of the library.

If it's an internal library for testing purposes, like gtest, then it should be handled outside the scope of ign-cmake, using an ordinary add_library(~) command.

If it's a library that we intend to ship and install as part of the project, then it should be added as a component library.

If we have a use case where we want to compile multiple libraries to be part of the "core" of a project but we want to keep them as separate libraries for some reason, we can revisit this macro. I think doing that could create a great deal of confusion, though, if only because it's hard to imagine what kind of naming convention we could even use for those libraries, e.g. libignition-transport1-core1 and libignition-transport1-core2?

So for now, I'd recommend we stick to the design of having one core library and arbitrarily many component libraries. This seems to be a popular pattern among modular library projects.

content.raw: Thanks for the clarification.
content.html: Thanks for the clarification.

content.raw: Is there any way we can test this pull request? Maybe the branch you mentioned in `ign-common`?
content.html: Is there any way we can test this pull request? Maybe the branch you mentioned in ign-common?

content.html: Yeah, I've been testing it against ign-common quite a bit. content.raw:
Now that pull request #51 has been merged, it should be mostly okay to merge this one into default.

However, much of our CI is expecting the `default` branch to provide `ign-cmake0`, but this pull request will change that to `ign-cmake1`.

I think before merging this branch, it will be crucial to update all of our CI to use the `ign-cmake0` branch instead of `default`.
content.html:
Now that pull request #51 has been merged, it should be mostly okay to merge this one into default.

However, much of our CI is expecting the default branch to provide ign-cmake0, but this pull request will change that to ign-cmake1.

I think before merging this branch, it will be crucial to update all of our CI to use the ign-cmake0 branch instead of default.

this broke the homebrew build because there isn't an ignition-cmake1 formula

* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_cmake-ci-default-homebrew-amd64&build=37)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_cmake-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/37/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_cmake-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/37/

I just added aliases for ignition-cmake1, which fixed it

* https://github.com/osrf/homebrew-simulation/commit/8e50a27813226355ed3dc05f8f88bacc2da240ae
* [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_cmake-ci-default-homebrew-amd64&build=38)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_cmake-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/38/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_cmake-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/38/

please remember to run and review results of all CI jobs while reviewing pull requests
